links.title: The Hum - Wikipedia
links.description: The Hum is a name often given to widespread reports of a persistent and invasive low-frequency humming, rumbling, or droning noise not audible to all people. Hums have been widely reported by national media in the UK and the United States, and sometimes named according to the locality where the problem has been particularly publicized: e.g., the "Bristol Hum", the "Taos Hum" and the "Windsor Hum."[1]

links.title: BART says its trains are quieter. But can they still damage your eardrums?
links.description: Noise is a complaint that BART hears often. Despite the incoming new fleet of cars - which the transit agency promises will be much quieter than the current trains - BART has continued to make improvements on its legacy fleet in order to reduce the noise for riders in the meantime. But is there still a chance you can damage your eardrums on trains?

links.title: Aeolian harp - Wikipedia
links.description: An Aeolian harp (also wind harp) is a musical instrument that is played by the wind. Named for Aeolus, the ancient Greek god of the wind, the traditional Aeolian harp is essentially a wooden box including a sounding board, with strings stretched lengthwise across two bridges. It is often placed in a slightly opened window where the wind can blow across the strings to produce sounds. The strings can be made of different materials (or thicknesses) ...

links.title: Box-drawing character - Wikipedia
links.description:
Box-drawing characters, also known as line-drawing characters, are a form of semigraphics widely used in text user interfaces to draw various geometric frames and boxes.
Box-drawing characters typically only work well with monospaced fonts.
In graphical user interfaces, these characters are much less useful as it is more simple and appropriate to draw lines and rectangles directly with graphical APIs.
However, they are still useful for command-li...

links.title: Free user space for non-graphics drivers
links.description:
In the kernel graphics world, there has been a longstanding "line in the sand" that disallows merging
kernel drivers without a corresponding free-software user-space driver.  The idea is that
not having a way to test  the full functionality means that the kernel
developers cannot verify the proper functioning and security of the
driver; changes to the kernel driver may lead to unforeseen (and
untestable) problems on the user-space side.   More re...

links.title: Sixel - Wikipedia
links.description: Sixel, short for "six pixels", is a bitmap graphics format supported by terminals and printers from DEC. It consists of a pattern six pixels high and one wide, resulting in 64 possible patterns. Each possible pattern is assigned an ASCII character, making the sixels easy to transmit on 7-bit serial links.

links.title: Atmospheric escape - Wikipedia
links.description: Atmospheric escape is the loss of planetary atmospheric gases to outer space. links.title: Standard cubic feet per minute - Wikipedia
links.description: Standard cubic feet per minute (scfm) is the molar flow rate of a gas corrected to "standardized" conditions of temperature and pressure thus representing a fixed number of moles of gas regardless of composition and actual flow conditions. It is related to the mass flow rate of the gas by a multiplicative constant which depends only on the molecular weight of the gas. There are different standard conditions for temperature and pressure, so care i...
